text: The US officials say they believe the American soldier who crossed the border between North and South Korea has been detained by North Korean authorities. American officials say the soldier had been in South Korea facing disciplinary action and decided to flee to the North while on his way to the airport to be repatriated. The heavily fortified demilitarized zone on the border between the two Koreas. And this is where the US soldier identified as Private Travis King was on a border tour when he crossed into North Korea. An eyewitness said he heard the soldier laughing loudly before making a run. But that dash has sparked a diplomatic flurry. The US and North Korea do not have official relations. US military authorities say they are working with their counterparts in North Korea to resolve the incident. That we're still trying to learn but what we do know is that one of our service members who was on a tour will fully and without authorization cross the military demarcation line. We believe that he is in the BRK custody. And so we're closely monitoring and investigating the situation and working to notify the soldiers next of kin. The soldier is not the first American to cross into North Korea. In the past, those who got over the border were detained even if they entered as tourists. Diplomatic efforts freed most of them but one tragic case ended in death. US student Otto Warmbier was detained in North Korea in 2016. He died days after being sent back to the United States in a coma in 2017. This latest incident comes as tension has been rising again in the region. On Wednesday, North Korea fired two ballistic missiles. This was after the arrival of a US nuclear submarine in the Korean peninsula. We get more on this from Kim Yun-sung, a reporter at Arirang TV in Seoul. Tell us more about this incident. What actually happened here? Right. So, here's what we do know so far. Around 3.27 p.m. Tuesday, this US soldier who was part of a tour group of the joint security area just dashed over the military demarcation line and went into North Korea. Officials didn't have enough time to react. They couldn't stop this man from crossing over this border. Also, we know that he was a low-ranking soldier, a private second class. From sources, I have heard that he's had a bit of disciplinary problems in the past, which has kind of kept him from advancing through the ranks. So that also gives a new dimension to this situation. I was actually supposed to be part of a press tour group to the JSA tomorrow, but that's been canceled since this incident. So the UN command is taking this very seriously. Okay, I've been on one of those tours before. I've been into that little blue room, but having gone through the next door, which leads into North Korea, and getting through that door isn't that easy. I mean, there are guards standing all around. There are guards on the other side with weapons, and there are automatic weapons set up everywhere. How is it possible that he managed to get through? Right, so it does definitely seem like an unlikely scenario. First of all, the motivation to dash into one of the most controlled and heavily impoverished states does seem a little weak. But also, I would like to say that the military demarcation line at Panmunjom and the joint security area is just a line on the ground. There's a little bump, and there's a clear paint crossed over the line. But just crossing over that de facto border would only take a step. So even though it does seem highly unlikely and very difficult, it is possible. Okay, and tell us about the possible fate of the soldier. The US and North Korea haven't got diplomatic relations. They haven't talked to each other in years. Right, it's very hard to say as of now. Like you said, the US has a very tenuous grasp on the situation because the US and North Korea does not have diplomatic relations. There has been cases in the past. For example, in 2017, a US national, Otto Warmbier, was detained in DPRK custody, and he was later returned home in 2017. There was also a case in 2018 where a US national has crossed over from China to North Korea and was also detained. But since we're dealing with a very rare case here, it's very difficult to say what to expect from now. Also, I've been contacting the press office of the UN command. They've been very unresponsive, and it's very hard to say of what to expect. The other thing is that this all happened as the US and South Korea met to discuss how to respond in the event of nuclear war with the North. Can you tell us more about those talks? Right, so the nuclear consultative group, that was something that was materialized during the Washington Declaration. They held their first inaugural session on Tuesday, also on the day that Travis King crossed over to the North Korean border, to the North Korean side. It seems that North Korea is very unhappy with these developments, since these nuclear consultative bodies, they're supposed to strengthen extended deterrence. And also, from your report, I've also heard that the USS Kentucky, the strategic submarine ballistic nuclear, has also visited Busan in more than four decades on Tuesday. So there is a lot of tension rising in the Korean peninsula, especially with this new development with the US soldier going into North Korea. We don't know what's going to happen at the moment. Will North Korea use this as a new card to play? That's something to be looked out for. Maybe an opportunity to start talking again, who knows? Joon-young Kim, Yon Sung, journalist with Arirang TV in Seoul, thank you very much.
